fields.descriptive_line: Portrait miniature of Mrs Marinus van Vrybergen, watercolour on vellum by Susannah-Penelope Rosse, ca.1690.

fields.name: Artists of the Tudor Court: the portrait miniature rediscovered, 1520-1620
Special Exhibition of Works of Art at the South Kensington Museum

fields.physical_description: Portrait of a woman, half-length, to front and wearing a headdress; oval on a rectangular sheet.  Features in soft brown hatches blended with blue and white, with black in the eyes and red in the lips, on a pale off-white carnation ground; hair washed in pale brown gouache over pale brown; head-dress in white and greenish brown; dress in a solid blue wash, with darker colour and white for the lights; mantle in grey gouache, lined in red and with the lights in pale pink hatches; lace at the breast in impasted white over grey; background in brown wash, darker to the left, pale to the right; on vellum put down on a leaf from a table-book.
fields.dimensions: Height: 96 mm sheet, Width: 67 mm sheet, Height: 70 mm oval, Width: 57 mm oval
fields.title: Mrs Vrybergen
fields.materials_techniques: Watercolour on vellum put down on a leaf from a table-book
fields.exhibition_history:
Exhibition of Portrait Miniatures (Burlington Fine Arts Club 1889-1889)
Special Exhibition of Works of Art at the South Kensington Museum (Victoria and Albert Museum 1862-1862)
Artists of the Tudor Court: the portrait miniature rediscovered, 1520-1620 (Victoria and Albert Museum 09/07/1983-06/11/19833)
fields.bibliography: Murdoch, John. Seventeenth-century English Miniatures in the Collection of the Victoria & Albert Museum, London: The Stationery Office in association with the Victoria & Albert Museum, 1997. Cat.145, pp.247-248. Full Citation: “145 Mrs Marinus van Vrybergen (b.c.1659) c.1690 455-1892 Rectangular 96 x 67 mm with a drawn oval 70 x 57 mm Features in soft brown hatches blended with blue and white, with black in the eyes and red in the lips, on a pale off-white carnation ground; hair washed in pale brown gouache over pale brown; head-dress in white and greenish brown; dress in a solid blue wash, with darker colour and white for the lights; mantle in grey gouache, lined in red and with the lights in pale pink hatches; lace at the breast in impasted white over grey; background in brown wash, darker to the left, pale to the right; on vellum put down on a leaf from a table-book. Condition: Engrimed, rubbed, discoloured in the facial area; losses especially in the impasted white; oxidised whites reverted in 1902, and the miniature treated again for oxidation in May 1938; otherwise sound. Signed: Not signed. Inscribed in metal-point (?) on the back: Mrs Vryberge. Frame: From The Pocket Book; see Cat. No. 87. [460-1892] Provenance: As for Cat. No. 88. [Presumably acquired from Cooper's estate by the Rosses, or perhaps by Priestman (see Rosse, Cat. No. 143) and perhaps in the Michael Rosse sale, 2 April 1723; eventually purchased by Edwin [Durning] Lawrence before 1862, and sold by him to the Museum for £525 in 1892.] Exhibited: As. for Cat. No. 88. [South Kensington 1862, no. 2531 (the set as Cooper); BFAC 1889, p. 133, case XLI, nos 1-15 (Cooper); V&A 1983, unnumbered.] Literature: As for Cat. No. 88 for general references [Literature: Williamson 1904, vol. I, pp. 51-2 (on the set, reproducing four by Rosse); Foster 1898, p. 40; Foster 1903, vol. I, p. 53 (tentatively attributing the set to Flatman); Foster 1908, p. 184 (as attributed to Cooper, but Foster would give some to Dixon; he now states that some give the poorer ones to Flatman); Catalogue of Miniatures , 1908, pp. 9-10 (as formerly attributed to Cooper); Goulding 1914-15, p. 49 (as Rosse); Long 1929, p. 377 (Rosse); Long 1930, pp. 65-6 (as by Rosse); Reynolds 1952, pp. 81-2 (Rosse); Foskett 1963, pp. 77-8; Foskett 1972, vol I, p. 481 (Rosse); Foskett 1974, p. 91 (Rosse); Reynolds 1975, specifically p. 9, no. 1, pl. 13; Foskett 1979, pp. 125-6 (following Reynolds 1975); Summary Catalogue , 1981, p. 9 (Cooper); V J Murrell, 'The Craft of the Miniaturist' , Murdoch 1981, p. 12, fig. 14 (as Cooper); V J Murrell, 'Technique and Practice', Strong 1983, p. 28, no. 1; Reynolds 1988, p. 78 and specifically pp. 59 and 78]; specifically, Reynolds 1975, no. 7, repro. pl. 21; Foskett 1979, pl. 25b; Reynolds 1988, p. 78, fig. 43. Dated by Reynolds c.1690 on the advice of Mad elei ne Ginsburg. (1) Ginsburg considered the coiffure and head-dress closely comparable to that in Cat. No. 146, and compared the scarf to that in the portrait of Mme de Maintenon (see entry for Cat. No. 141). She added the thought that the present miniature was 'marginally earlier' than either Cat. Nos 141 or 146. The sitter was Anne Gibson, younger surviving daughter of Richard Gibson (q.v.), by his wife Anne Sheppard. She spells her name with a final e, rather than a, in her signature witnessing the death of her father and the finding of his will in July 1690. The inscription on the back of the miniature refers to her by her married name. The story of her marriage, summarised from a deposition of 24 September 1681, made by Richard Gibson to the Hof van Holland, was published by A Bredius. (2) As an unmarried daughter, Anne accompanied her parents when they went to Holland in the suite of Princess Mary in 1677. The family lodged initially in Amsterdam, at the house of Johan Nieulant, a silversmith in the Singel. Shortly after, when the Gibson parents had to return to England on business, Nieulant and his housekeeper were placed in charge of Anne, and they allowed her to receive visits from a young man, Marinus Dibbouts van Vrijbergen, the son of Bonifacius van Vrijbergen, a Deputy in the States General. Although Marinus was still legally a minor, he appears to have been a councillor in the Sovereign Council of Brabant. His visits to Anne Gibson were received on the basis that he would, in due course, obtain the approval of her father to seek her hand in marriage. For reasons that are not clear, however, Anne consented to a private marriage on 14 November 1679, in the presence of 'a Romish priest named Lodovicus Hachoanus de Bruij, a missionary of English Nationality here at the Hague, with a promise to celebrate the marriage publicly at the first opportunity'. The couple then lived together. Anne in due course became pregnant, and with the approval of her husband set off in October 1680 for England in order to give birth. In England she stayed with her mother and brother, her father having meanwhile returned to The Hague. She received numerous affectionate letters from her husband, which included affectionate messages from her 'dear little father'. The child was born in 1681, a daughter who was named Elizabeth after Marinus's mother. But meanwhile Richard Gibson discovered that Marinus had formed an affection for another woman, in whose favour he wished to repudiate his marriage to Anne. In September 1681, therefore, Richard sued the van Vrijbergens in the Dutch courts, requiring that Marinus should make good his promise to marry Anne publicly in a church. The Gibsons won, but, as part of the arrangement, Anne signed a deed promising not to compel Marinus to co-habit with her. Thereafter, Anne lived with her parents, evidently returned with them to England in 1688, took up residence in Henrietta Street with Susannah-Penelope and Michael Rosse, and witnessed with them and two of her brothers the finding of her father's will in 1690. 1 Minute of December 1974, departmental files. 2 Bredius 1910.”
fields.history_note: <u>Provenance:</u> Presumably acquired from Cooper's estate by the Rosses, or perhaps by Priestman (see Rosse, Cat.  No. 143) and perhaps in the Michael Rosse sale, 2 April 1723; eventually purchased by Edwin [Durning] Lawrence  before 1862, and sold by him to the Museum for £525 in 1892.
